images.description: The flight and back-up crews for NASA's first manned Apollo Block II spaceflight at a press conference and design review meeting at the North American plant.
(description not yet available)
Apollo Atlantic Recovery
Apollo 7 Astronauts (l-r) Walter M. Schirra, Jr., Walter Cunningham, and Donn F. Eisele,  shake hands with USS Essex cooks.
Apollo 7 Astronauts (front-to-rear) Walter M. Schirra, Jr., Donn F. Eisele,  and Walter Cunningham are greeted by officials upon their arrival by aircraft to Cape Kennedy's skid strip today.

Apollo 7 Commander Walter M. Schirra, Jr., right, flew the last 420 miles of his successful space mission in a twin-engine aircraft today between the USS Essex, prime recovery ship, and Cape Kennedy's skid strip.
Apollo 7 Commander Walter M. Schirra, Jr.,kneels on flight deck of the USS Essex to check landing gear of aircraft which later flew him from the aircraft carrier to Cape Kennedy's skid strip.
Apollo 7 astronauts (l-r) Walter Cunningham, Donn F. Eisele, and Walter M. Schirra, Jr., compare notes at a mission debriefing conducted today at the Kennedy SpaceCenter.

Astronaut John W. Young, back-up Command Module pilot for the first manned Apollo mission moves from the center couch position to the equipment bay in the Command Module simulator in Building 5 at the Manned Spacecraft Center.
The prime crew for Apollo 7 mission scheduled later his year went through spacecraft egress training today at the Kennedy Space Center.
Astronaut Donn Eisele waits to have his space suit adjusted preparatory to entering the Apollo 7 spacecraft for manned simulate altitude runs in the Spaceport's altitude chamber.
Astronaut Walter M. Schirra, Command pilot of the Apollo 7 is assisted by a suit technician for the manned altitude run in the altitude chamber.
Astronaut Donn Eisele leaves the Suiting facility in the Manned Spacecraft OperationsBuilding on his way to the altitude chamber.
Astronaut Walter M. Schirra is inserted into the Apollo 7 spacecraft in the altitude chamber of the Manned Spacecraft Operations Building.
Astronaut Donn Eisele, Command Module Pilot for the first Manned Orbital Apollo Mission, Apollo 7, inside the spacecraft in a simulated altitude test.

The prime crew for Apollo 7, the first manned Apollo flight, (l-r) Astronauts Donn F. Eisele, Command Module Pilot; Walter Cunningham, Lunar Module Pilot; and Walter M. Schirra, Jr., Commander, after completing egress training at Galveston Bay, TX.
The backup crew for Apollo 7 (l-r) Astronauts Eugene A. Cernan, John W. Young, and Thomas P. Stafford, after completing egress training at Calveston Bay, TX.

Apollo 7 Prime Crew Members (l-r) Donn F. Eisele, Walter M. Schirra, Jr., and Walter Cunningham relax after today's successful Space Vehicle Emergency Egress tests conducted at Cape Kennedy's Launch Complex 34.
(description not yet available)
The prime crew for Apollo 7, Walter Cunningham, Donn F. Eisele, and Walter M. Schirra, Jr., after completing egress training at Galverston Bay, TX.
